results.title: Living in & belonging to a place
results.creator_credit: Barbara Pater, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Barbara Pater provides some insight into what it is like to have an acquired brain injury. Some people want to retreat from the world and some join their local community group but all struggle to restore a sense of dignity.

results.title: Living free
results.creator_credit: Jack Couffer, Paul Radin, Carl Foreman and Columbia
results.brief_description: The sequel to “Born free” continues the adventures of Joy and George Adamson. Elsa the lioness brings her three cubs out of the wilderness to the couple who raised her. When Elsa suddenly dies, the cubs who cannot fend for themselves, attack domestic animals to survive before disappearing into the wild. The Adamson’s launch a desperate attempt to find the young lions and bring them to the safety of the game reserve. Starring Susan Hampshire and Nigel Davenport.

results.title: Living dangerously
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Recommends precautions against bush fires in outer-suburban and rural areas. Common fire hazards on suburban properties include undergrowth and scrub on fences, overhanging trees, cluttered spoutings, absence of fly wire on doors and windows to prevent entry of sparks; absence of incinerators and compost heaps to dispose of rubbish. In rural areas the responsibility of the inidividual is greater. The film shows examples of bad fire hazards; crops growing close to buildings; absence of fire breaks; litter strewn over properties. Stresses the need to check spark arrestors on machinery and to maintain fire fighting gear in working condition. In one year, bush fires cost the country fourteen million pounds, a loss which could have been avoided by people being wise before the event. Photography by Frank Bagnall.

results.title: Living colors = Vivre en couleurs
results.creator_credit: Michel Hebert, Francine Desbiens and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Charcoal drawings depict the bleak world of the worker. Pastel drawings illustrate his dreams. Oftentimes, they are dreams created by the media. Are they tailored to his real needs? Or his pocket book? This film comments indirectly on the impact of publicity and its power to develop appetites that cannot be satisfied. An animation film without words.

results.title: Living cells
results.brief_description: Uses the phase contrast optical system to show that living cells are very active structures. Shows how movement can be detected in the cytoplasm of the cells, ranging from a streaming movement of the early cytoplasm to movements by a whole variety of cellular organelles. The cell surface also exhibits movement, and even in the case of multicellularorganisms, movement of the whole cell can be observed. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Living Ballarat: 1901-1941
results.brief_description: Meticulously restored and accompanied by an authoritative commentary and period music, this program includes events captured on film by Australia’s first permanent Film Unit, the Salvation Army’s Limelight Department, Ballarat’s first Film Unit (producer of Australia’s first provincial newsreel, Pathe’s Ballarat Gazette), the Commonwealth Government’s chief cinematographer, Bert Ive; and amateur cine enthusiasts of the 1930s. Film historian, Chris Long, researched this video and prepared the commentary for the National Film and Sound Archive. It is one of a series of video which brings history to life while giving public access to Australia’s heritage of actuality and documentary film.

results.title: Living arts of Japan
results.brief_description: Visitors to Japan rarely have time or opportunity to examine closely the cultural activities shown in this film: from the measured dignity of the tea ceremony to the delicate brushwork of Japanese paintings, the perfection of lacquer-ware and the vigorous manufacture of wood block prints.

results.title: Living and Non-living things (US)
results.brief_description: Looks at what living and non-living things do that makes them differ, using two young boys at play in a suburban back-yard, a dog having puppies, a car etc, to illustrate this point. Educational Collaborator: George G. Mallinson, Michigan University.
